messages.title: Labour kick-starts election campaign
messages.content: As the election campaign officially gets underway, Labour has revealed its five pledges to the people of Britain ahead of the General Election on 7 May.

messages.title: REVEALED: NIGEL FARAGE WANTS TO SCRAP OUR FREE NHS
messages.content: Nigel Farage has been caught on camera suggesting the UK should scrap our free NHS and replace it with an American-style healthcare system.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: A BETTER PLAN FOR WORKING FAMILIES
keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour's commitments will not require any extra borrowing.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: AN NHS WITH THE TIME TO CARE
keyPolicies.policyDescription: The Tories have caused the worst A&E crisis on record. Labour will secure 20,000 more nurses and 8,000 more GPs to 'make sure our NHS has the time to care for patients'.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: Higher living standards for working families
keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour will ensure the burden fairly by reversing the Tory tax cut for millionaires, and clamping down on tax avoidance, introducing a tax on properties worth over £2 million to secure the future of our NHS.

issues.economy: Labour has set out a plan to build a strong economic foundation and balance the books. The plan will cut the deficit every year without more, moment of Labour's manifesto commitments will require extra borrowing.
issues.education: Under the Tories, tuition fees have trebled, apprenticeships for young people are falling, and there are over 750,000 unemployed young people. Labour will reduce tuition fees by £3,000, guarantee an apprenticeship for every school leaver who gets the basic grades, ensure smaller class sizes for 5, 6 and 7-year-olds, and put teaching standards first.
issues.health: Labour will recruit 20,000 more nurses and 8,000 more GPs to 'make sure our NHS has the time to care for patients'.

images.caption: Labour leader Ed Miliband launches Labour’s plan for more doctors and nurses with health professional.
Ed Miliband meets Rosie, a medical student from Newcastle, at a junior doctors conference in Manchester.
